purpose.summary: This policy establishes compliance standards for state wage and hour laws affecting sales compensation across the Company's multi-state operations. State laws impose varying requirements for commission agreements, payment timing, final pay, and recordkeeping. This policy ensures the Company complies with all applicable state requirements while maintaining consistent compensation practices.
objectives: Establish compliance standards for state wage and hour laws affecting sales compensation
Ensure compliance with varying state requirements for commission agreements, payment timing, final pay, and recordkeeping
Maintain consistent compensation practices across multi-state operations
Provide specific California Labor Code compliance guidance
Define final payment procedures for employee termination

appliesTo: All sales compensation arrangements for employees working in the United States
Commission, bonus, and incentive payments subject to state wage laws

definitions.definition: Compensation earned as a percentage or amount based on sales transactions. Generally considered 'earned wages' under state law once the triggering event (sale, payment, delivery) occurs.
Discretionary compensation not directly tied to specific sales. May be treated differently than commissions under state law.
Critical distinction in many states. 'Earned' commissions must typically be paid on termination; 'unearned' commissions may be forfeited. States define 'earned' differently.
The last paycheck provided to a terminated employee, including all earned wages, accrued vacation (in some states), and earned commissions.
Reduction from compensation. Many states restrict deductions from commission payments.
Statutory penalties (e.g., one day of pay for each day payment is late) imposed by some states when final pay is not timely provided.

provisions.title: State Wage Law Overview
provisions.content: States have widely varying laws governing sales compensation. Non-compliance can result in significant penalties.

subProvisions.title: Why State Compliance Matters
subProvisions.content: Non-compliance with state wage laws can result in:
items: Wage claims and litigation by employees
State labor department penalties and investigations
Requirement to immediately pay disputed commissions
Attorney's fees and penalty wages (2x or 3x in some states)
Class action exposure for systemic violations

subProvisions.title: Key Areas of State Variation
subProvisions.content: States differ significantly on:
items: Whether written commission agreements are required
Timing of final commission payment upon termination
Whether commissions can be subject to clawback
Classification of commissions vs. bonuses
Frequency of commission payments during employment
Recordkeeping requirements

provisions.title: California Labor Code Requirements
provisions.content: California has the most extensive and employee-friendly commission laws in the country. Given the Company's significant California operations, California compliance is critical.

subProvisions.title: Written Commission Agreement Requirement (Labor Code Section 2751)
subProvisions.content: California REQUIRES a written commission agreement signed by both employer and employee that includes:
items: Method of computing commissions
When commissions are 'earned' (vesting trigger)
Payment frequency during employment
Treatment upon termination
Must be signed before employee earns any commissions
Employee must receive copy of signed agreement
Any modifications must be in writing and signed
Failure to have written agreement creates presumption in employee's favor in disputes

subProvisions.title: Final Payment Timing (Labor Code Sections 201-202)
subProvisions.content: California has strict final payment deadlines:
items: Involuntary Termination: All earned wages (including commissions) due immediately at termination
'Immediately' means at time of termination meeting
Can mail if employee doesn't return to pick up (postmarked within 24 hours)
Voluntary Resignation: All earned wages due within 72 hours
If employee gives 72+ hours notice, due on last day of work
Only 'earned' commissions must be paid immediately
Commission agreement defines when commissions are 'earned'
If commission not yet calculable, must estimate and pay within reasonable time
Waiting time penalties apply if payment is late (up to 30 days of pay)

subProvisions.title: Clawback Restrictions
subProvisions.content: California significantly restricts commission clawbacks:
items: Cannot deduct from final pay without employee's written authorization
Cannot require repayment of earned commissions (except for advances or draws)
'Earned' commissions generally cannot be clawed back for returns/cancellations
Commission agreement must clearly define when commissions vest (become 'earned')

subProvisions.title: Recordkeeping (Labor Code Section 226)
subProvisions.content: California requires detailed recordkeeping:
items: Itemized wage statements showing all compensation components
Commission calculations must be accessible to employees
Records retained for 4 years
Employees have right to inspect/copy payroll records
Penalties for inaccurate wage statements: $50 first violation, $100 each subsequent (up to $4,000)

provisions.title: Key Multi-State Requirements
provisions.content: State-by-state requirements for written agreements, final payment timing, and commission classification.

subProvisions.title: Commission vs. Bonus Classification
subProvisions.content: Many states distinguish between commissions and bonuses for legal purposes. Most Company sales incentive plans are commissions (non-discretionary, formula-based). Plans should be designed and documented as commissions with clear earning criteria to avoid disputes.
items: Commission: Earned based on specific, measurable sales activities; non-discretionary; generally must be paid on termination if 'earned'; subject to stricter state law requirements
Bonus: Discretionary payment not tied to specific formula; employer retains discretion on amount and payment; may not be due on termination; generally more flexibility in plan design

provisions.title: Commission Agreement Standards
provisions.content: Standards for all sales compensation plan documents to ensure state law compliance.

subProvisions.title: Required Contents
subProvisions.content: All sales compensation plan documents must include:
items: Clear calculation formula or methodology
Definition of when commissions are 'earned' (vesting trigger)
Payment timing during active employment
Treatment of commissions upon termination
Clawback provisions (if any) clearly defined
Dispute resolution process
Governing law and jurisdiction

subProvisions.title: State-Specific Language
subProvisions.content: For California employees, commission agreements must additionally include:
items: Explicit reference to California Labor Code Section 2751
Statement that agreement complies with California law
Employee acknowledgment of receipt of signed copy

subProvisions.title: Timing of Signature
subProvisions.content: Requirements for when commission agreements must be signed:
items: California: Must be signed BEFORE employee earns any commissions
Other states: Best practice to obtain signature before first commission earned
New hires: Include in offer letter or onboarding package
Existing employees: Obtain signature on new agreements before effective date

subProvisions.title: Plan Changes and Amendments
subProvisions.content: Any changes to commission plan terms require:
items: Written amendment or new agreement
Employee signature (especially in California)
Reasonable notice period (30-60 days preferred)
Cannot be applied retroactively to already-earned commissions

provisions.title: Final Payment Procedures
provisions.content: Procedures for processing final compensation payments upon employee termination.

subProvisions.title: Termination Notification to Payroll
subProvisions.content: HR must notify Payroll and Sales Compensation immediately upon employee termination:
items: Termination date
Type (voluntary vs. involuntary)
Work state (for determining final pay timing)
Active commission plans and pending payments

subProvisions.title: Commission Calculation for Final Pay
subProvisions.content: Process for calculating final commission payments:
items: Earned Commissions: Identify all transactions meeting 'earned' criteria per plan document, calculate through last day of employment, include pending from prior periods if 'earned'
Unearned Commissions: Identify transactions not yet meeting 'earned' criteria, apply plan terms regarding forfeiture or future payment, document basis for excluding from final pay
Estimates: If exact calculation not possible by final pay deadline, estimate conservatively (high), true-up within 30 days, document estimation methodology

subProvisions.title: Final Pay Processing by State
subProvisions.content: State-specific final pay processing requirements:
items: California Involuntary: Process check for pickup at termination meeting or mail immediately
California Voluntary: Process within 72 hours (or last day if notice given)
California: Include all earned commissions even if not yet calculated (estimate if needed)
All Other States: Follow state-specific timing requirements, include earned commissions per plan terms, document compliance with applicable state law

subProvisions.title: Annual Plan Disclosure
subProvisions.content: Each year, all commissioned employees receive:
items: Updated compensation plan document
Summary of key terms in plain language
Contact information for questions
Acknowledgment form for signature

subProvisions.title: Required Acknowledgments
subProvisions.content: Employee acknowledgment must state:
items: 'I have received and read the [Plan Name] compensation plan'
'I understand how my compensation is calculated'
'I understand when commissions are earned and payable'
'I have been provided opportunity to ask questions'
Date and signature

subProvisions.title: Mid-Year Changes Notice
subProvisions.content: When compensation plans change mid-year:
items: 30-day advance written notice (60 days preferred)
Clear explanation of changes
Effective date
New acknowledgment form
Cannot change treatment of already-earned commissions

provisions.title: Record Retention Requirements
provisions.content: The Company maintains compensation records per the most stringent state requirements.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring and Audits
provisions.content: Ongoing monitoring and audit procedures for state wage law compliance.

subProvisions.title: Quarterly Compliance Checklist
subProvisions.content: Sales Compensation and HR conduct quarterly review:
items: All active commissioned employees have signed commission agreements on file
California agreements comply with Labor Code Section 2751 requirements
Commission payments processed within required timeframes
Final payments for terminated employees met state deadlines
No waiting time penalty situations identified

subProvisions.title: Annual State Law Update Review
subProvisions.content: Legal department conducts annual review of:
items: State wage law changes affecting sales compensation
New states where the Company has commissioned employees
Court decisions impacting commission law
Needed policy or plan document updates

subProvisions.title: High-Risk State Focus
subProvisions.content: California operations receive enhanced monitoring:
items: Monthly review of California terminations for final pay compliance
Verification all California employees have Labor Code Section 2751 compliant agreements
Quarterly training for California HR and payroll staff
Annual legal audit of California commission practices

provisions.title: Roles and Responsibilities
provisions.content: Clearly defined roles for all parties involved in state wage law compliance.

subProvisions.title: Sales Compensation Team
subProvisions.content: Primary responsibilities:
items: Design commission plans compliant with state laws
Ensure all plans have required written agreement components
Obtain employee signatures on commission agreements
Calculate earned commissions for final pay
Maintain commission agreement files

subProvisions.title: Human Resources
subProvisions.content: Employee management:
items: Distribute commission agreements during onboarding
Notify Payroll and Sales Comp of terminations immediately
Track final pay deadlines by state
Maintain state law compliance calendar
Coordinate with Legal on state law changes

subProvisions.title: Payroll
subProvisions.content: Payment processing:
items: Process final payments per state deadlines
Include earned commissions in final checks
Maintain pay records per state retention requirements
Produce itemized wage statements (California)
Flag late payment risks to HR

subProvisions.title: Legal Department
subProvisions.content: Legal compliance:
items: Review commission agreements for state law compliance
Monitor state wage law changes
Advise on California Labor Code Section 2751 compliance
Provide annual state law training
Handle wage claims and disputes

subProvisions.title: Finance
subProvisions.content: Financial management:
items: Ensure proper accruals for earned commissions
Budget for final commission payments
Maintain records per state requirements
